title: Pregnant Cyrell Paule reveals how cruel racist comments from trolls took a toll on her relationship
text:
Married At First Sight's Cyrell Paule has revealed how cruel and racist comments from trolls took a toll on her relationship with Eden Dally.

The 31-year-old, who is pregnant with her first child, told Daily Mail Australia on Thursday that she and Eden often fought because of the stress of it all.

'It did a lot of damage, even with us, as much as it hurts to say it. It caused arguments,' Cyrell said.

'It did a lot of damage': Married At First Sight's Cyrell Paule has revealed how cruel and racist comments from trolls took a toll on her relationship with Eden Dally

'That was terrible and probably the worst [part],' Cyrell said.

She added that Eden told her to ignore the trolls, but the negative comments still upset her - especially when racists told her boyfriend to 'leave his black monkey'.

'Eden told me, "Why are we listening to the worst of others, when we should be believing in each other?"' she said.

'The truth of the matter is, you try and do that but it still hurts - and to top it off, [the stress] then goes onto your child.'

Conflict: The 31-year-old, who is pregnant with her first child, told Daily Mail Australia on Thursday that she and Eden often fought because of the stress of it all

Cyrell was horrified when trolls said they wanted her to have a miscarriage.

'Fair enough if you want to say what you want about Eden and I, but when I hear people praying that they want me to have a miscarriage... that's too far,' she said.

'They started saying, "Your baby is going to be half black".

'It did a lot of damage, even with us, as much as it hurts to say it,' Cyrell said

'I was like, "What?" Just because of my skin colour, my kid now needs to die? And I'm already hormonal as it is!'

Eden explained that he was forced take Cyrell's phone away from her so she could ignore the keyboard warriors.

The couple are supporting the Heart on my Sleeve Pledge for World Mental Health Day, which encourages people to speak up if they need help.

A good cause: The couple are supporting the Heart on my Sleeve Pledge for World Mental Health Day, which encourages people to speak up if they need help

Eden said he wants trolling to be made illegal, adding that the current laws aren't tough enough.

But for now, he and Cyrell are trying to use their profile for a good cause, hence why they are supporting World Mental Health Day.

'We have a platform to reach out to a wide audience so we may as well use it to do good,' Eden said.
description: Married At First Sight's Cyrell Paule has revealed how cruel and racist comments from trolls took a toll on her relationship with Eden Dally.
authors: Chloe-Lee Longhetti For Daily Mail Australia
